So it was once a dimension that I selected.  Then it became a parameter.  That’s why this is sort of an edge case, but it is certainly a bug.

Hey Yogesh,

Just to clarify you have your own oauth2 server and need to configure this to connect with looker?

So you would not be using any of the following IdPs?

Types of IdPs Supported In Looker:

Looker currently supports 4 IdPs that are mutually exclusive; that is, you can only have one enabled at a time. The supported IdPs are:

-

Google OAuth (also known as Google Auth or Google OAuth)

-

SAML (Security Assertion Markup Language)

-

LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol)

-

OIDC (OpenID Connect aka OpenID OAuth)

-Dave

> > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > That makes sense. If keeping a completely separate environment for testing is the concern, then a staging instance sounds like the best path forward.
> > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >

> > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I did want to note that an additional staging instance does come with a cost. I've looped in my colleague, Alec to the chain to discuss the cost implications for this set up. Just a heads up that he is out of office but will be back tomorrow.
> > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > It is also worth noting that spinning up a new staging instance replica will require some downtime to perform. And once you have 2 instances, they will become out of sync with each other. As you continue to create users on your main (production instance), you will need to duplicate work on your staging instances to keep them aligned.

Hi Chris, Hi Rachel



We have made some progress on isolating the issue:



We now have a scale-able k6 performance test which replicates the usage pattern of our app. Out main findings are:



1. the individual request performance (meaning 1 user making sequential requests)  is actually good (~500ms-1000ms) when using pure http request via k6 (in contrast to our previous finding, where we used the ruby-loooker-sdk stack). **=> we need to evaluate how to make this faster, but it's not a main concern right now**

2. The concurrent request performance is where things get slow: depending on the instance size, request times shoot up at 10-14+ requests per second. **=> We need to figure out where the bottleneck for the concurrency is as our most important issue!**



While Guy is working on splitting up the _run_inline_query_ request into a _create_query_ and _run_query_ request Justin tried to identify a potential bottleneck on (our?) the infrastructure side:



From Justin:



> I spent Sat & today testing Looker 6.6.14-9bbe18 on a dedicated EC2 instance. I went through 31 iterations of our k6 test suite and have come away with some good news and some not-so-good news.
>
>
>
> All the evidence collected so far points to the fact that, for our current configuration and use pattern, Looker simply consumes an unusual amount of resources. It requires a relatively large amount of RAM and CPU per request per second. The good news is that it's maximum requests/sec do appear to scale up with resources available in a roughly linear fashion, and with some Looker specific tuning and architectural changes we can get our baseline performance-per-vCPU up. That means vertical scaling will alleviate at least some of our pain. The bad news is that vertical scaling won't be enough to reach 200 reqs/sec. The largest available EC2 instances on AWS today would barely get us to that number, if at all. The largest c4 class EC2 instance will only get us about 50 reqs/sec.
>
>
>
> Test results to date indicate that Looker can achieve approximately **2 requests/sec/vCPU** on a c4 class instance, given adequate memory for the java process. There are some additional gains to be had with tuning options such as a MySQL back end vs HyperSQL(*), extremely high IOPS storage for Looker such as a tmpfs ram disk(**), and adjustments to java memory allocation and runtime parameters(***). None of these adjustments provide enough gains to get us to our 200 req/sec goal, but they do help. Cumulatively the gains are something like 20 or 25%, but it's better than nothing.
>
>
>
> Our current c4.2xlarge EC2 instances running Looker, with the above tuning, can achieve about 20 reqs/sec. That scales up to the largest available c4 class instance, the c4.8xlarge, at roughly 50 reqs/sec.
>
>
>
> I've used a lot of hedged wording above like approximately, roughly, nearly, and around. The purpose of all my testing was not to rigorously quantify every tiny deviation in synthetic test performance but instead to quickly identify the major variables that are affecting our performance. Sadly, it appears to be good old CPU overhead, with HyperSQL vs MySQL running a distant second (which is more evidence that we might just be asking too much of Looker internally... I can only guess what its doing with it's currently 660MB HyperSQL database).
>
>
>
> - justin
>
>
>
> * Looker docs recommend migrating from HyperSQL to MySQL for the Looker db backend when the HyperSQL db > 600MB. We are at 660MB on our test instance. I'm super curious what is being kept in there. It could be related to our performance issues.
>
>
>
> ** I/O throughput to local block devices does not seem to be a significant factor in performance, even with the current st1 volumes. Extremely performant IO paths like RAM disks obviously do make a difference, but IO is not the primary bottleneck here.
>
>
>
> *** Looker documentation exposes only a handful of supported tunable configuration options that are likely to affect reqs/sec throughput. They were all tested and produced negligible or even deleterious effects on performance. There is some evidence that these tunables could increase performance on the very largest EC2 instance classes (i.e. ones with large amounts RAM), but even in the unlikely scenario that we achieved a 50% performance improvement we will still be hard pressed to get our targeted 200 req/sec from a single EC2 instance of any class.



What catches my eye is "Test results to date indicate that Looker can achieve approximately **2 requests/sec/vCPU** on a c4 class instance, given adequate memory for the java process."


1. this seems to be extremely low

2. is this the performance we should expect or does this look fishy to you folks?



What's next:

- We would like to get some guidance if what we are seeing here is normal.
- We are splitting up the _run_inline_query_ request into a _create_query_ and _run_query_ request right now and will get back with result.
- We would like to have a temporary **hosted instance** for these performance tests, to which we can hook up our Snowflake DB and our Model and run the k6 performance tests against these. That eliminates flaws in our infrastructure setup and also give you from looker the ability to have an in depth look at the problem and tweak it.



Thank you very much,



Sebastian


P.S. Please add Justin jlott@square-root.com and Randy rpond@square-root.com to the zendek ticket so they are able to reply to questions.




--

**Square Root, Inc.**

Hey all,

Wanted to send some updates on things Mark and I discussed yesterday as well as follow up on some of the points in Molly's email.

First, we're definitely curious to hear if the IOPS changes have any impact on the tests so please do let us know the results once you've given that a shot.

To summarize where we stand thus far, Chris originally was working on this ticket with you and as the topic became more complex we escalated to involve Molly, one of our Technical Support Engineers, to bring in her additional expertise. Molly has also brought in some engineers and gone through the logs and other details with them to be sure she is performing a thorough investigation, bringing forth all possible ideas and adjustments. I spoke with leadership here and there are specific requirements that need to be met for us to send resources on site and at this time those requirements are not being met. Both Molly and the engineers she is working with are happy to continue investigating though we do acknowledge that the timeline we have available is not a full match to your own.

As such, there are some options to get additional, more dedicated resources to help your team look into this issue. Both our Professional Services team or our network of partners are a great asset when it comes to getting more personalized help. In this case, as our team specializes in all things Looker and this issue covers also the network and infrastructure, I would likely recommend one of our partners as they have a greater knowledge of full stack troubleshooting and optimization. If this is something that is of interest and you would like to get in touch with one of our partners on a scoping call we are happy to arrange that meeting.

Finally, I am heading out of office this weekend until July 2nd. In my absence, my manager Brian LaFaille will be covering for me and taking over as your main point of contact. His email is brian@looker.com and he is included in this thread.

Best,

Rachel

>

> datawarehouse-stg1

> 3306
>

>

 On Wed, Jun 12, 2019 11:03 AM, Adam Cunnington adam.cunnington@2sixty.io wrote:


> Hi Jon, Zara, Kab,
>
>
> Please excuse the out of the blue email but we have an urgent query.
>
>
>
> We are trying to export some data from Looker to GCS. The data we are exporting uses our Presto connection which in turn connects to other sources.
>
>
>
> Looker, Presto and the other sources (bar 1 source) all reside within a gcloud network protected by CloudFlare. When we run the query from the Looker UI, it appears to run fine (although have not yet seen it complete). As soon as we issue an export job via the "Send" option, it consistently fails after 100 seconds and Looker instead writes an error file to GCS. When I download this error file and rename to .html and open in my browser, I see that it is an error generated by CloudFlare:
>
> ![image.png](https://help.looker.com/attachments/token/dVZTY0k8ynX2jFlXS0IXzqGK3/?name=image.png)
>
> _Note: In the error message, the IP highlighted is an AWS EC2 IP that I do not recognise (although **may** be SAP - more on this later)._
>
>
>
> Our google cloud network is protected by CloudFlare and it is expected behaviour for CloudFlare to terminate any open connections external to the network perimeter after 100 seconds. What does not make sense here is why there is any communication external to our network perimeter.
>
>
>
> The only thing I can think of is that 1 of the connections that Presto uses goes via a VPN tunnel to an external application inside of AWS. The data we are exporting does not use any data points from this source but I'm unsure whether Presto would open a socket regardless. In any case, it doesn't make sense to me that we experience this timeout when exporting data whilst we don't appear to experience this timeout when running the query ad-hoc via the UI.
>
>
>
> To summarise, the question is "why is a different network path generated by the export job vs. running the query ad-hoc in the UI"?
>
>
>
> Thanks,
>
> Adam

> What we have observed is that the logic for Access Filters is no longer applying the same SQL logic. We restrict our partners access to their “content provider” value. What this typical looks like is a SQL “in statement”. However, this logic is being ignored is now being translated into a string with an “= statement” instead of an “in” statement or a wildcard like ‘%’ for default values.
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> For instance this is now the below query and will return no values because the logic has changed. We need to resolve this ASAP as our partners are not happy at all. Please advise and sorry for looping everyone in but this is urgent.
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> SELECT
>
>
>
>             metadata.artist  AS "metadata.artist"
>
>
>
> FROM public.meta  AS metadata
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> WHERE (metadata.artist = 'Taylor Swift') AND (metadata.contentprovider = 'umg,umgi') AND (metadata.repowner = '%, NULL')
>
>
>
> GROUP BY 1
>
>
>
> ORDER BY 1
>
>
>
> LIMIT 500
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

>

> }

> >
> > I would suggest adding Name and potentially Email measures to get more information about each user.
> >
> >
> >
> > **Data Model Bloat and Cleanup **
> >
> > **a.  Basic tips for instance cleanup:**
> >
> > 1. Deleted and Unused Content for Admins: As of Looker version 5.6, there's the Unused Content and Trash sections within the Browse section of your Looker. This allows you to analyze what data hasn't been viewed in a certain number of days and delete (you can restore content if needed because it's a soft delete). We recommend using this feature to improve content search-ability, ease of spaces navigation, and content validator speed.
> > 2. Content Validation: In version 5.12 we introduced deletion from the content validator.
> > 3. Using i__looker model: The i__looker meta model provides insight surrounding overall Looker usage. In the linked discourse article, you'll see a number of query patterns that can be used to identify unused explores and views. This can be a great way to get rid of model bloat, and narrow down the number of relevant explores that end-users toggle.
> > 4. Finding Unused Fields: This article leverages the API to clean up unused fields in the model/explore.
> >
> > ** b. Henry Tool **
> >
> > As we discussed, one of our colleagues on our Customer Success Engineering team recently built a nifty tool called Henry that can be used by LookML developers/admins to help clean up Looker models and perform an overall health check of a Looker instance. This Discourse Article will also provide some insight.
> >
> >
> >
> > There are three main commands that can be leveraged: pulse, analyze, and vacuum. Here's a quick overview of what each command can do at a high-level, and more details can be found in the wiki in the link I shared above.
> >
> > - **Pulse: **Determines overall instance health by testing all connections, checking the current Looker version, checking stats on queries and scheduled plans, and checking for any legacy features that are in use.
> > - **Analyze**: Scans all projects for their content, scans all models and outputs the number of explores and queries run in each, and scans all explores to show their usage and the features being utilized on each.
> > - **Vacuum:** Outputs a list of unused content based on predefined criteria that you can then use to clean up models and explores.
> >
> >
> >
> > This is unfortunately not an official supported product of Looker, but I'd be happy to loop in my colleague who created Henry, Joseph, for any questions that you may have. Here is also a discourse article with more information. We'd love to hear your feedback if you had a chance to test it out!
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > **c. Looker Professional Services: Health Check / Model Cleanup**
> >
> > As a third option I think it may also be helpful to connect with our professional services team and talk about what they may be able to do to help clean up - I'm thinking the professional services team may be able to help speed up the clean up as they have been doing these exercises more often now as our accounts start to age and experience this model bloat issue.
> >
> >
> >
> > I hope this information helps! Please let me know if you would like to setup a followup call to go over any of these ideas.
> >

 On Tue, Jun 18, 2019 12:46 PM, Avery Robins success@looker.com wrote:


> Hi Emily,
>
>
>
> Totally understand how annoying that can be. Down with the slowness! Let me dive into a few things here.
>
>
>
> It's important to consider instance performance in two ways:
>
> 1. the time it takes to load the dashboard (cpu)
> 2. the time it takes for the individual tiles to load (database)
>
> If you have a way to review your CPU usage, we highly recommend doing so!
>
>
>
>  A few things to consider:
>
> - keeping your dashboard below 25 tiles
> - closing multiple browser windows or lots of tabs when accessing Looker
> - restarting your machine daily
> - make sure your browser is up to date
>
> Check out our articles: "Factors Impacting Query Performance", and "Best Practices: Optimize Looker Performance" and let me know if these suggestions help with your page responsiveness.
>
>
>
> Secondly, sometimes load on your instance can be unintentionally high. Often this is caused by a user who has set an auto-refresh rate on dashboard that is very high.
>
>
>
> You can use the following Explore in your Looker to isolate behaviors like these and drive a more efficient workflow.

>
>

Hi Hina,


Yes, it's possible to connect to Spark Tables on Amazon EMR. Amazon EMR is a managed cluster platform that can run Spark. So, it just comes down to how the specific thrift server for Spark is installed. More info about this is found in our Spark DB config instructions.



Best,

> Don’t think that’s possible since we have not added embed_domain until now.  Below is our url generator.  Note the only change we added (see // BEFORE) is adding ${embedDomain} to the path before the querystring.stringify(…), which is just:
>
>
>
> `%3Fembed_domain=http://localhost:3000`
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Wonder if you have seen the “refused to connect” (previous attachment) before.
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> const genSignedUrl = (secret, hostPort, options) => {
>
>
>
>   const json = jsonify(options);
>
>
>
>   const embedPath = '/login/embed/' + encodeURIComponent(options.embedPath);
>
>
>
>   const embedDomain = `%3Fembed_domain=http://localhost:3000`;
>
>
>
>   const signature = crypto
>
>
>
>     .createHmac('sha1', secret)
>
>
>
>     .update(buildSignature(json, hostPort, embedPath))
>
>
>
>     .digest('base64').trim();
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> // BEFORE:
>
>
>
> //  const result = `https://${hostPort}${embedPath}?` + querystring.stringify({
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>   const result = `https://${hostPort}${embedPath}${embedDomain}?` + querystring.stringify({
>
>
>
>     nonce: json.nonce,
>
>
>
>     time: json.time,
>
>
>
>     session_length: json.session_length,
>
>
>
>     external_user_id: json.external_user_id,
>
>
>
>     permissions: json.permissions,
>
>
>
>     models: json.models,
>
>
>
>     group_ids: json.group_ids,
>
>
>
>     external_group_id: json.external_group_id,
>
>
>
>     user_attributes: json.user_attributes,
>
>
>
>     access_filters: json.access_filters,
>
>
>
>     first_name: json.first_name,
>
>
>
>     last_name: json.last_name,
>
>
>
>     force_logout_login: json.force_logout_login,
>
>
>
>     signature: signature
>
>
>
>   });
>
>
>
>   return result;
>
>
>
> }
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Thanks.
>
>
>
> John

Hi Jon,

I found that the charset of tables are 'utf8' and the charset of DB is 'latin1'.



I created mysql DB instance in RDS for the test. The 'character_set_server' is 'latin1' as default. I created table using this query.



'REATE TABLE `companys` ( `id` int(11) NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT COMMENT 'id ユーザ詳細ID', `code` varchar(36) NOT NULL, `user_id` varchar(36) NOT NULL, `name` varchar(255) DEFAULT NULL COMMENT '会社名', `nickname` varchar(255) DEFAULT NULL, PRIMARY KEY (`id`), UNIQUE KEY `user_id` (`user_id`), UNIQUE KEY `companys_code_unique` (`code`), KEY `companys_nickname_index` (`nickname`) ) ENGINE=InnoDB AUTO_INCREMENT=5133 DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8 COMMENT='companys''



Then I inserted some data including Japanese characters into this 'companys' table and run this query on SQL Runner.

'SELECT * FROM mariko_stage.companys where nickname ='テスト''



SQL Runner sais 'No Results'.

But I can get result using same query in my local MySQL Workbench.



I attached these result.



Is this a bug?

> **LOOKER CONFIDENTIAL**
>
>
>
> Dear Customer,
>
>
>
> Looker identified and resolved two critical security bugs in the Looker application last week that could lead to unintentional information disclosure within the context of a Look or Explore. While the likelihood of exploitation is low, upon identifying the vulnerabilities, Looker’s Engineering and Security teams immediately began working on a fix that is now available. Refer to the “Recommended action for both issues” section below for download instructions.
>
>
>
> **Recommended action for both issues:**
>
>
>
> We’ve applied a fix to all supported releases and strongly advise you to update to a patched release in order to address this vulnerability. If you are on Looker-Hosted, there is no action necessary as this has already been fully patched.
>
>
>
> Please take a moment to ensure that you are on one of the following patch releases.
>
>
> - 6.10.20+
> - 6.8.34+
> - 6.6.39+ (Extended Support Release)
>
>
> In order to get the patched release, please visit https://download.looker.com/validate and enter your email address, license key, and select “Latest Version” or enter one of the following file names:
>
>
> - looker-6.10-latest.jar
> - looker-6.8-latest.jar
> - looker-6.6-latest.jar (Extended Support Release)
>
>
> If you have any additional questions, please reach out to our Support team by completing the online form on our Help Center site found under "Contact Us".
>
>
>
> https://help.looker.com/hc/en-us
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Sincerely,
>
>
>
> Looker Security
>
>
>
> * * *
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> **Details:**
>
>
>
> **Issue 1: Access filter bug on Native Derived Tables (NDT)**
>
>
>
> **Overview:**
>
>
>
> The Looker application’s access filters when used in conjunction with Native Derived Tables (NDT), contains a vulnerability when a user attribute is utilized as a filter.
>
>
>
> **Impacted versions:**
>
>
>
> Looker versions 5.0.0 through 6.10.18 are impacted.
>
>
>
> **Details:**
>
>
>
> On May 14, 2019, Looker determined that this issue occurs when a Native Derived Table (NDT) is relying on access filters from its underlying Explores to filter the data presented to the user.  When a user attribute is selected, changes to the user attribute value may not be reflected in the resulting SQL query for the NDT. In some circumstances, the updated access filter may not be applied, which may result in invalid data being pulled from the cached NDT.  A user must already have appropriate permissions to access the database connection of the underlying explores to access the affected NDT.  If the access filter is applied directly to the LookML of the NDT explore, the filters will be applied to the query and behave as expected.
>
>
>
> **Solution:**
>
>
>
> This issue has been resolved in the following versions: 6.10.20+, 6.8.34+, and 6.6.39+, so an upgrade to one of these versions is recommended if operating an older version of Looker.
>
>
>
> Looker Hosted
>
>
>
> As of May 15, 2019, all Looker hosted customers have been fully patched for this issue.
>
>
>
> Customer Hosted
>
>
>
> Customers who have installed Looker on customer’s premises or a customer-controlled server within a third-party data center, will need to immediately install the hotfix via the links below in order to fully remediate this issue.
>
>
>
> If you are unable to immediately upgrade your Looker application, please  take the following steps to mitigate your exposure:
>
>
>
> Copy the access_filters from the NDT’s Explore source and paste them directly in the Explore referencing that NDT. Any Explores referencing an NDT with applied access_filters should have those same access_filters applied to them. While these steps will resolve this vulnerability, we strongly recommend that you upgrade the Looker application as soon as possible, in order to apply our latest security patch.
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> **Issue 2: Incorrect escaping in non-advanced access filters**
>
>
>
> **Overview:**
>
>
>
> The Looker application’s use of non-advanced user attributes as access filters may generate unexpected results, when leveraging the “-” syntax.
>
>
>
> **Impacted versions:**
>
>
>
> Looker versions 5.22.0 through 6.10.18 are impacted.
>
>
>
> **Details:**
>
>
>
> On May 15, 2019, Looker discovered an incorrect SQL statement is generated by the Looker application when a user leverages non-advance user attribute of type string with access filters.  This changes the sql syntax to a “does not equal” statement and drops the “-” character from the attribute value. Upon execution of the generated SQL statement, incorrect results are rendered to screen since the filter value was not properly parsed by the Looker application. Please note that the user creating the explore must already have access to the model in order to be impacted by the outlined issue.
>
>
>
> **Solution:**
>
>
>
> This issue has been resolved in the following versions: 6.10.20+, 6.8.34+, and 6.6.39+, so an upgrade to one of these versions is recommended for those on older versions of Looker.
>
>
>
> Looker Hosted
>
>
>
> As of May 16, 2019, all Looker hosted customers have been fully patched for this issue.
>
>
>
> Customer Hosted
>
>
>
> Customers who have installed Looker on customer’s premises or a customer-controlled server within a third-party data center, will need to immediately install the hotfix via the links below in order to fully remediate this issue.
>
>
>
> If you are unable to immediately upgrade your Looker application, please  take the following steps to mitigate your exposure to this issue:
>
>
> 1. Identify the access filter referencing a user attribute of type string that leads with “-” character.
> 2. Replace the access filter with a  sql_always_where: on the explore using liquid to pull the desired user attribute. Example: sql_always_where: filter_field = ' ' ;;
>
>

Hi Snehal,


     Thank you for your patience as I worked to get you updates on your tickets.



     As you may have seen already, our Support team has been in touch with Srishti on the tickets, requesting additional info to reproduce the bugs.  Thank you for responding to these requests; please continue to communicate with our Support team on the individual tickets.  Also, our Engineering team has been notified of these bugs and we are working to escalate your 3 top issues to a high priority internally.



     That said, I am unable to provide an expected timeline to resolution at the moment.  Our development and release cycles is focussed on providing robust, long-term resolution that work well and as expected.  This means that we have to evaluate and validate every bug properly and find the best way to address them, which takes some time.  I can reassure you though that we are doing everything we can to provide the quickest and best support possible.



     In the meantime, can I ask you to try the following:

     (1) For the issue where the top left viz's top portion is cut off, please add another tile on top of it, with some header text perhaps, and see if that sufficiently pushes the graph viz down so it is not cut off.

     (2) Similarly, for the issue where X axis labels are cut off, maybe you can add a blank tile below and see if that helps.

     (3) For the repeated labels issue, I noticed there were two adjacent tiles.  Maybe you can keep the two tiles on two rows and see if that makes the full y-axis labels appear?



     I will continue to provide updates for you as I get additional info.  And on that note, please be aware that I am on vacation next week but I have apprised my colleague Mark Grossman (mark.grossman@looker.com) of the situation and he will get in touch with you in my stead.  Let us continue to use this email thread for this discussion.





Regards,



Prashant Ramachandran

 On Fri, May 31, 2019 9:02 AM, Tommy McCarthy tommy.mccarthy@autodesk.com wrote:

Hi Yair and Roman,



     I had a read through the ticket.  Last activity on that is a question from our Support team to clarify your aggregation requirement.  Based on the example provided, it seems like a valid question to ask: How would you want to "aggregate" the value 3281 for the Beer sub?  Do a sum?  Do an average?  To me as well, it looks like what you are wanting here is not aggregation but in fact removing duplicate results.



     If that is the case, I can point you to this article (which I am sure is what Support would have done as well): https://discourse.looker.com/t/subtotals-with-table-calculations/7261  You can create a table calc to generate a rank value which you can then wrap inside another if-statement to create Yes and No values which you can subsequently use to filter the results (Filter out all No values).  Here's an example:

_if(if(match(${orders.status},${orders.status})=offset(match(${orders.status},${orders.status}),-1), 1+row()-match(${orders.status},${orders.status}), 1)=1,yes,no)_



     I will also add that if you anticipate more of these requests and would like extended support from an expert, my recommendation is that you consider another Professional Services SOW where you will have access again to a dedicated consultant.  I recall Aleks mentioning that you probably could do well with approximately 10 more hours of PS support.  Let me know what you think.







Regards,

Hi Yan,



Nice to me meet you!  I'm happy to help with an upgrade strategy.  With these upgrades, I generally like to upgrade the dev instance, ensure everything works smoothly then upgrade prod.



Conviva has two instances.  From what I can tell your development instance is hosted by you and the production instance is hosted by us.  To streamline the upgrade process and make it easier moving forward, would you be open to moving the dev instance to Looker Hosted as well?  This way we can push upgrades there, you can confirm they are healthy and working correctly, then we can upgrade the production instance.



I can answer a few of the questions above too:



1. Since production is hosted by us, we capture backups and can manage any rollback necessary.  Downtime is 15-30 minutes during our upgrade time.

2. We can definitely do this upgrade prior to 5/31

3. I'd recommend upgrading your dev instance to the desired production version.  Once we confirm dev is good to go, we can upgrade prod.  (this would be easier if both instances were Looker Hosted and you could leverage us for all the upgrading and backup work)

4.  Completely understand.  Our generally upgrade windows are between 9-11 PM PDT.  However, I'd be happy to coordinate a specific time with our team to ensure your team is online as well.



Hope this helps, Yan!  The major takeaway is that I'd like your team to evaluate moving the dev instance to Looker Hosted to we can coordinate upgrades more smoothly.  Let me know if that works for you.



All the best,

Paul

Paul Mathewson | Customer Success Manager

Join Us for Office Hours!

Hi Yan,



No problem - happy to help out wherever I can!  I'm glad to hear the testing on dev is coming along well.  Let us know if you run in to any issues.  You are spot on about the custom visualization regression.  We try to limit those problems as much as possible.



**Upgrade**

- There's nothing to be done on your end to reduce the downtime
- This rarely takes longer than 15 minutes but plan for 30 just in case
- Let's schedule this for **5/29 at 10 PM PDT**

**Hosted Dev**

- I think the on-prem dev is actually OK after receiving this information from you and chatting with my team
- I also understand the dev team is largely in China and should Looker host it you may run in to speed issues
- Let'd keep dev where it is for now
- Always happy to evaluate this moving forward

**Single Nod Prod Concerns**

- Valid concern that Prod is only single node
- We should upgrade Conviva to a clustered, HA environment
- Graham (your AE, cc'd here) and myself caught up with Sanjay yesterday to discuss clustering your environment
- We're working through the license amendment as we speak
- We currently do not not support **rolling upgrades** on our clustered environments.  When we upgrade a clustered instance, we will have to take offline the entire instance and upgrade nodes one by one then start the nodes one by one again. Otherwise the internal database will be corrupted

**Rollback**

- Plan for 2 hours
- Usually complete in under an hour (sometimes under 30 minutes)

Please confirm that we can schedule the upgrade for **10 PM PDT on 5/29** and I will ask my operations team to perform the upgrade at that time.  If you have any other questions, let me know.



All the best,

Paul

Hi all,



     Thank you for your time earlier today.  Here's a summary of the priority we assigned on the tickets:



1. P1s are high priority; these are tickets that have forced you to keep your paid enterprise analytics offering on beta and hence need quick resolution.  Three tickets are **P1**: **225107**, **225121**, and **225122**.



2. P2s are issues that confuse your users and/or take away from the users' experience. These are not deal breaker issues at the moment but still will be better off getting fixed or addressed sooner rather than later. Five tickets are **P2**: **224911**, **225110**, **225112**, **225116**, and **225118**.



3. P3s are minor issues and they we can wait to get resolved. Four tickets are **P3**: **224915**, **225108**, **225113**, and **225117**.



     At the moment, I am working with our Support function to reproduce the P1 issues and escalate priority with our Engineering team.  I will keep you posted.





Regards,

Hi guys,



We got an email via their CEO on this as it affects their customers



tl;dr: Kate from Marketii spoke to DCL regarding a look containing survey records that doesn't open the actual survey from Looker (apparently it worked before). DCL confirmed it's more of an issue with how their data is stored in the database.   There is a nice thread on this here in Slack that references their email and the chat.

https://looker.slack.com/archives/CABJ08P0D/p1559294707008500

Here is a link to the ticket: https://looker.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/221942



We went back to the customer to let them know its an issue with their data that they need to resolve.  To which they just now responded:



> “We have located one of the files in question in blob storage where Looker retrieve the survey files from, so the file is available. The DataDump table contains the expected ContactDataID and the Warehouse table contains the correct Survey Id. So everything looks good from our perspective.
>
> My only question would be whether the query Looker are using that is returning a NULL Id has changed or is not joining to the correct table for Email Surveys?
>
> What table they get the ContactDataID to view the survey and check that that survey html file exists in Blob storage?
>
> Both the Datadump table & Warehouse table have rows with that ContactDataId = 4016926 & SurveyID = 4016926, so there may be something wrong with their query that is returning NULL for SurveyID”



Is this something we can resolve with them?



Appreciate your urgency on this, we're also negotiating their renewal so it's a bit of a tricky time for us.



Thanks

Mark

> > **LOOKER CONFIDENTIAL**
> >
> >
> >
> > Dear Customer,
> >
> >
> >
> > Looker identified and resolved two critical security bugs in the Looker application last week that could lead to unintentional information disclosure within the context of a Look or Explore. While the likelihood of exploitation is low, upon identifying the vulnerabilities, Looker’s Engineering and Security teams immediately began working on a fix that is now available. Refer to the “Recommended action for both issues” section below for download instructions.
> >
> >
> >
> > **Recommended action for both issues:**
> >
> >
> >
> > We’ve applied a fix to all supported releases and strongly advise you to update to a patched release in order to address this vulnerability. If you are on Looker-Hosted, there is no action necessary as this has already been fully patched.
> >
> >
> >
> > Please take a moment to ensure that you are on one of the following patch releases.
> >
> >
> > - 6.10.20+
> > - 6.8.34+
> > - 6.6.39+ (Extended Support Release)
> >
> >
> > In order to get the patched release, please visit https://download.looker.com/validate and enter your email address, license key, and select “Latest Version” or enter one of the following file names:
> >
> >
> > - looker-6.10-latest.jar
> > - looker-6.8-latest.jar
> > - looker-6.6-latest.jar (Extended Support Release)
> >
> >
> > If you have any additional questions, please reach out to our Support team by completing the online form on our Help Center site found under "Contact Us".
> >
> >
> >
> > https://help.looker.com/hc/en-us
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > Sincerely,
> >
> >
> >
> > Looker Security
> >
> >
> >
> > * * *
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > **Details:**
> >
> >
> >
> > **Issue 1: Access filter bug on Native Derived Tables (NDT)**
> >
> >
> >
> > **Overview:**
> >
> >
> >
> > The Looker application’s access filters when used in conjunction with Native Derived Tables (NDT), contains a vulnerability when a user attribute is utilized as a filter.
> >
> >
> >
> > **Impacted versions:**
> >
> >
> >
> > Looker versions 5.0.0 through 6.10.18 are impacted.
> >
> >
> >
> > **Details:**
> >
> >
> >
> > On May 14, 2019, Looker determined that this issue occurs when a Native Derived Table (NDT) is relying on access filters from its underlying Explores to filter the data presented to the user.  When a user attribute is selected, changes to the user attribute value may not be reflected in the resulting SQL query for the NDT. In some circumstances, the updated access filter may not be applied, which may result in invalid data being pulled from the cached NDT.  A user must already have appropriate permissions to access the database connection of the underlying explores to access the affected NDT.  If the access filter is applied directly to the LookML of the NDT explore, the filters will be applied to the query and behave as expected.
> >
> >
> >
> > **Solution:**
> >
> >
> >
> > This issue has been resolved in the following versions: 6.10.20+, 6.8.34+, and 6.6.39+, so an upgrade to one of these versions is recommended if operating an older version of Looker.
> >
> >
> >
> > Looker Hosted
> >
> >
> >
> > As of May 15, 2019, all Looker hosted customers have been fully patched for this issue.
> >
> >
> >
> > Customer Hosted
> >
> >
> >
> > Customers who have installed Looker on customer’s premises or a customer-controlled server within a third-party data center, will need to immediately install the hotfix via the links below in order to fully remediate this issue.
> >
> >
> >
> > If you are unable to immediately upgrade your Looker application, please  take the following steps to mitigate your exposure:
> >
> >
> >
> > Copy the access_filters from the NDT’s Explore source and paste them directly in the Explore referencing that NDT. Any Explores referencing an NDT with applied access_filters should have those same access_filters applied to them. While these steps will resolve this vulnerability, we strongly recommend that you upgrade the Looker application as soon as possible, in order to apply our latest security patch.
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > **Issue 2: Incorrect escaping in non-advanced access filters**
> >
> >
> >
> > **Overview:**
> >
> >
> >
> > The Looker application’s use of non-advanced user attributes as access filters may generate unexpected results, when leveraging the “-” syntax.
> >
> >
> >
> > **Impacted versions:**
> >
> >
> >
> > Looker versions 5.22.0 through 6.10.18 are impacted.
> >
> >
> >
> > **Details:**
> >
> >
> >
> > On May 15, 2019, Looker discovered an incorrect SQL statement is generated by the Looker application when a user leverages non-advance user attribute of type string with access filters.  This changes the sql syntax to a “does not equal” statement and drops the “-” character from the attribute value. Upon execution of the generated SQL statement, incorrect results are rendered to screen since the filter value was not properly parsed by the Looker application. Please note that the user creating the explore must already have access to the model in order to be impacted by the outlined issue.
> >
> >
> >
> > **Solution:**
> >
> >
> >
> > This issue has been resolved in the following versions: 6.10.20+, 6.8.34+, and 6.6.39+, so an upgrade to one of these versions is recommended for those on older versions of Looker.
> >
> >
> >
> > Looker Hosted
> >
> >
> >
> > As of May 16, 2019, all Looker hosted customers have been fully patched for this issue.
> >
> >
> >
> > Customer Hosted
> >
> >
> >
> > Customers who have installed Looker on customer’s premises or a customer-controlled server within a third-party data center, will need to immediately install the hotfix via the links below in order to fully remediate this issue.
> >
> >
> >
> > If you are unable to immediately upgrade your Looker application, please  take the following steps to mitigate your exposure to this issue:
> >
> >
> > 1. Identify the access filter referencing a user attribute of type string that leads with “-” character.
> > 2. Replace the access filter with a  sql_always_where: on the explore using liquid to pull the desired user attribute. Example: sql_always_where: filter_field = ' ' ;;
> >
> >
> > **Additional information**:
> >
> >
> >
> > The following links have further update-related information:
> >
> >
> > - JAR download
> > - Download instructions
> > - Update Instructions
> > - Currently supported releases
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >

 On Wed, Jun 19, 2019 10:48 AM, Benjamin Lutz blutz@billtrust.com wrote:


> Hello,
>
>
> Looking forward to talking with you, wanted to share just a touch more information. As we're deleting these, we also run into errors that seem to occur after a sustained period of requests. We'll try to delete groups, it can return a 500 (probably a timeout), but eventually succeeds on the server and the group is deleted. After too many of these timeouts, we'll get a large number of 500 responses almost instantly from Looker. My guess is that the server is overloaded, and is unable to handle any more requests. Please see the example below. At the blue line, you can see that we're deleting a group, that took 100,035 ms. The next line is the same command, but returns within 100ms, and then all the requests below it fail quickly as well. If we sleep the script, Looker seems to recover after a few minutes, and we're able to run again. Increasing the timeout would allow us to get a better realistic view of when it's safe to send the next request and would decrease the amount of "dead time" that we have, as we try to not push Looker past an invisible line.

> - I think the on-prem dev is actually OK after receiving this information from you and chatting with my team
> - I also understand the dev team is largely in China and should Looker host it you may run in to speed issues
> - Let'd keep dev where it is for now
> - Always happy to evaluate this moving forward
>
>
>
> **Single Nod Prod Concerns**
>
>
>
> - Valid concern that Prod is only single node
> - We should upgrade Conviva to a clustered, HA environment
> - Graham (your AE, cc'd here) and myself caught up with Sanjay yesterday to discuss clustering your environment
> - We're working through the license amendment as we speak
> - We currently do not not support **rolling upgrades** on our clustered environments.  When we upgrade a clustered instance, we will have to take offline the entire instance and upgrade nodes one by one then start the nodes one by one again. Otherwise the internal database will be corrupted
>
>
>
> **Rollback**
>
>
>
> - Plan for 2 hours
> - Usually complete in under an hour (sometimes under 30 minutes)
>
>
>
> Please confirm that we can schedule the upgrade for **10 PM PDT on 5/29** and I will ask my operations team to perform the upgrade at that time.  If you have any other questions, let me know.

Zendesk Tickets Summary:
gospotcheck had an outage (JVM OOM and HTTPS unresponsive) on 1-12 that is suspected to be the consequence of running 3 hour + long downloads in tandem with other requests.

They had a similar outage on 1-22, but the root cause remains *much* more elusive.  It happened from 6-9pm PST  on 1-21 / 2-5 am UTC on 1-22.

We decided to upsize them to throw more memory at the problem.  Post-upsize, things look good, so solving

Zendesk Tickets Summary:
5/29: cigna gave vague information about the eng patch efficacy.  Having them run through our bash script to measure this efficacy.

cigna has had xlsx download issues for a year.  We changed our xlsx streamer in a custom jar, and post-update cigna is seeing a difference in behavior.  There are 3 new issues (DD-244,CORE-265,CORE-266) filed for this behavior.  

DD-244 isn't a priority but CORE-265/265 are since 100+ users depend on Jasper to export daily xlsx files, and they are sunsetting Jasper in June in the hopes that Looker can provide the same service.

cigna has had xlsx download issues for a year.  We changed our xlsx streamer in a custom jar, and post-update cigna is seeing a difference in behavior.  There are 3 new issues (DD-244,CORE-265,CORE-266) filed for this behavior.  

DD-244 isn't a priority but CORE-265/265 are since 100+ users depend on Jasper to export daily xlsx files, and they are sunsetting Jasper in June in the hopes that Looker can provide the same service.

We have been encountering a separate issue where some of the scheduled looks haven't been uploading to the SFTP even though they show as completed in the Scheduler History. Other reports that are being sent to the same SFTP are uploading without any problem. Is this related to the runtime issue. This causes a big problem on our end as it is not feasible for someone to go check if all the reports were uploaded to the respective folders in the SFTP every day and we are planning on roughly doubling the number of reports that are being sent via Looker.

Kanishk

Item Name : DCL Request
 Category : DCL
 Quantity : 1
 Subject : Bug - suggestions query does not use parameter value for sql_table_name
 Account Name or Instance Name : Como - como12.eu.looker.com
 Hosted By : Looker
 Looker Release : 6.12.19
 Severity : (Normal): Software usable but non-critical functionality or system components are affected while most operation is unaffected.
 Summary of Issue : It turns out that Looker does not pass the value from the parameter manually entered to the suggestions query. For example in this setup: view: users { sql_table_name: public.{% parameter manual_table_injection %} ;; parameter: manual_table_injection { type: unquoted } Where in the explore you'll manually type 'users' into parameter called manual_table_injection, any query will work just fine. However, if you'd like to get any suggestions for the string dimensions, they'll fail. That's because these queries will not include the parameter value in the suggestion queries. For example you'll get: SELECT AS "users.manual_table_injection" FROM public. AS users WHERE () ILIKE '%' OR () ILIKE '% %' GROUP BY 1 ORDER BY 1 LIMIT 1000 ....where you should get: SELECT AS "users.manual_table_injection" FROM public. users AS users WHERE () ILIKE '%' OR () ILIKE '% %' GROUP BY 1 ORDER BY 1 LIMIT 1000 Note that this will work when we specify the default_value on a parameter but that defeats the purpose. It needs to be dynamic even for suggestions. I've replicated on my local instance. Super easy to replicate. Just should if any questions. Customer will need to keep updated as it's pretty important to them.

 Subject : Orphaned credentials_saml row preventing returning intern from logging into meta.looker.com
 Account Name or Instance Name : meta.looker.com
 Hosted By : Looker
 Looker Release : 6.15.0000291
 Severity : (High): Software is operative but performance is seriously degraded or restricted with a significant impact on business operation.
 Summary of Issue : Quick note on Severity: Complete loss of functionality for 1 looker intern who needs access to meta.looker.com... so not sure where that fits in the sev schema. History: Xander was an intern for us last year (2018). When he left, his user was disabled. A few months ago, our team deleted disabled users for meta.looker.com. Current Problem: He onboarded yesterday (6/17/2019) as a returning intern. My understanding of the onboarding process was that everyone is put into the All Lookers AD group first day (or before), and then they can go to meta.looker.com/login and authenticate with Azure. When xander tries to do this, he can successfully authenticate with Azure, and IT and I can confirm we see a successful login event for him in AZURE. This brought me to the looker logs, where I noticed this 2019-06-18 16:54:51.722 +0000 [INFO|1412c|db:looker] :: (0.001675s) SELECT * FROM `credentials_saml` WHERE (`saml_user_id` = 'xander.olivero@looker.com') LIMIT 1 This made me look at the credentials_saml table, where i see this: https://meta.looker.com/sql/kv5nwrn8x4vpsw Note the created_date, logged_in_at and user_id. These are all from when xander was an intern last year, and refer to a user that no longer exists in the users table. I then checked out the users table, where we don't see a record for him, which _is_ expected https://meta.looker.com/sql/ktknqktsm9n8wy I asked in the sme-auth channel, jband had this which lines up with what I'm seeing "There is probably a stale credentials_saml row that contains the right external saml id (saml_user_id), but has a wrong/dead user_id" It seems like we aren't cleaning up the credentials_saml table when a user is deleted? In addition to following up with this with eng, If we could take some interim steps to get xander access we'd really appreciate it. Something like this happened to me a couple weeks ago, and Elijah had to manually prune some rows from the content_metadata_group_user table in meta's internal db. If something like that would get xander access that would be sweet. Thanks y'all!

Putting this back down to high since they are back up.

In the logs, there were a bunch of threads that had been running for a while associated with queries, mainly SQL Runner queries from the looks of it. From the timing script:

```
2019-01-07 07:14:23.791 +0000 => No end time found => (10c55) => 127.0.0.1 |10c54| POST /api/3.1/sql_queries/wjt2hgk5gsgd4b/run/json_fe, {}
```

The weird part is that these queries sent off a request to stream data in another thread:

```
2019-01-07 07:14:24.176 +0000 [INFO|10c55|http_core] :: (0.384712s) |10c54| Request result will stream: 200
```

And that completes just fine:

```
2019-01-07 07:14:24.178 +0000 [INFO|10c54|http_core] :: (0.386339s) Request complete: 200 (End streaming) Streamed 5364 chars.
```

I'm thinking there may be a bug in the timing script not parsing `Request result will stream: 200` correctly as the end of a thread, but need to verify 100% that that is indeed the end of the thread.

Also their memory usage slowly climbed up to the max allocated before the outage, but there were no OOM errors in the logs at all. CPU was fine. Getting access to ilooker would be the best path forward but I might be able to get that info from Pinger if they continue to not respond.

I don't think it's the cause of the outage, but they were also having issues with PDT queues getting longer due to locks on some tables Looker was trying to drop: #188289

"the name must be the same in both views"

Well, the value of the foreign_key is a dimension of only one view: the "from" side of the join relationship, if you will. The joined-in view's dimension is whatever is marked as the 'primary_key', no matter what its name is.

I'm surprised you're not encouraging it, as it is much less error-prone (but much less flexible, of course) than sql_on clauses.

# Summary

Julie came on chat asking about a few queries that took longer to run than usual (~60 seconds per query vs normal 4). These queries are asccoiated with dashboard 58 and the notable [spikes](https://looker-us.merrillcorp.com/explore/system__activity/history?qid=GZY3gNJSwGoCRlVkWee8n0&toggle=dat,vis) occurred at 11:01 and 11:05 UTC on [6/3](https://looker-us.merrillcorp.com/explore/system__activity/history?qid=qvBUbRivgAXMUhYPwukA5X&toggle=vis) and 9:02, 10:27, and 12:04 UTC on [6/8](https://looker-us.merrillcorp.com/explore/system__activity/history?qid=Me0vg3fd5xMW5CuJVjVjMb&toggle=vis).

### Resources
[**Datadog**](https://lookerdata.datadoghq.com/dashboard/43i-s55-nt5/looker-instance-performance?screenId=43i-s55-nt5&screenName=looker-instance-performance&from_ts=1559545200000&live=false&tile_size=m&to_ts=1559606340000&tpl_var_host=merrillus)
[**Pinger Dashboard**](https://meta.looker.com/dashboards/4173?Account%20Name=&Host%20name=merrillus&Time%20Range=2019%2F06%2F08&filter_config=%7B%22Account%20Name%22:%5B%7B%22type%22:%22%3D%22,%22values%22:%5B%7B%22constant%22:%22%22%7D,%7B%7D%5D,%22id%22:3%7D%5D,%22Host%20name%22:%5B%7B%22type%22:%22%3D%22,%22values%22:%5B%7B%22constant%22:%22merrillus%22%7D,%7B%7D%5D,%22id%22:4%7D%5D,%22Time%20Range%22:%5B%7B%22type%22:%22on%22,%22values%22:%5B%7B%22date%22:%222019-06-08T16:43:21.850Z%22,%22unit%22:%22day%22,%22tz%22:true,%22constant%22:%227%22%7D%5D,%22id%22:5%7D%5D%7D)
[**System Activity Dashboard**](https://looker-us.merrillcorp.com/dashboards/heap_block::sys_activity_performance_dashboard_udd)

Nothing stands out to me as a smoking gun across any of these. Generally, activity looks normal during these times and doesn't seem to explain the spikes.


### Other Findings
- The [Dashboard Performance](https://looker-us.merrillcorp.com/explore/system__activity/dashboard_performance?qid=cAWf7H5nUogpiuXka9VayE) system activity explore is showing some very high numbers for the "seconds until" fields for some dashboard runs on the 8th, though these queries are showing up as having run in a matter of seconds and the logs don't seem indicate anything suspicious about these queries.

- I also found a [bug](https://looker.atlassian.net/browse/IC-2016) that's coming up when this dashboard is run, showing `Rack app error: #<ArgumentError: invalid %-encoding` errors in the logs but I've found no indication that this is related. 

- The `query_summary` lines for the long running queries (pasted below) show everything but the SQL running quickly. 

- Something makes me think this is related to the filter values, however I have nothing to back up that theory.

Since we can only render two things at the same time (by default) two slow queries can back everything else up. So [the image download] jobs really are queued for rendering.

--scheduler-query-limit=<i> Limits number of concurrent scheduled queries
(default: 10)
--scheduler-query-timeout=<i> Length of scheduler timeout to wait for
connection (default: 1200)

Also render timeouts are 30 minutes and I don't think we can change those.

this dash

So they way it works in Looker.
1. queries got fired against your DB
2. once they return it begins renderring

# Summary so far by: _Gavin_

Nick is concerned about an episode last weekend where he feels that the data shown in Looker was nearly a day out of date. Unfortunately the details are not exactly clear (he cannot name a specific tile to investigate, for example) as it was reported to him by users.  The initial message was:
>I'm seeing our looker instance show data that is out of sync with our Redshift data warehouse. Our warehouse is showing data that is within 20 minutes of our production data (which is our planned schedule). However, when I query the same data from our existing looker dashboards it is showing that the data is almost 20 hours out of date.

I asked him to clarify how he checked that the data was out of date when he initially investigated the situation, and he detailed:

>1. In the looker dashboards I selected explore from here on the daily sales tile and then chose to clear cache and refresh to ensure that I was getting recent data. Doing this did not update the sales data and I was able to see we were not receiving orders for Saturday this way. 
2. I was able to see that the data was out of date by manually selecting recent orders in a separate explore. Orders stopped at 2 AM UTC even though it was around 11 PM UTC when I ran that query to list orders. 
3. I then checked tables in the warehouse directly using the SQL Runner (I shared those in the last email) to verify that the ETL job was updating data properly. The sql runner results were directly contradicting the dashboards and explores I had previously run.


**Ticket Priority:** 

## Low

**What's been covered so far?**

I've tried to check if the issue was related to caching, PDTs, datagroups etc. I've had to choose a particular tile to look at, as there are dozens of them and investigating all would take forever. As far as I can see, there is only one PDT involved, dim_calendar, which increments daily. I don't see any datagroups involved in the explore the tile is based on, but the tile has a persist_for of 30 minutes.

__I based my checks on one tile at the top left of the dashboard, Daily Gross Sales__

__The Explore has a 30 minute persist_for:__

explore: trans_date {
  from: dim_calendar
  label: "Transactional Date"
  hidden: no
  persist_for: "30 minutes" ----> __persist_for enables you to modify the amount of time that cached query results are used__ 

__dim_calendar is a derived table, with a SQL_Trigger_Value based on the current date:__

view: dim_calendar {
  derived_table: {
    sql:
    SELECT
      *,
      TO_CHAR(DATE_TRUNC('month', date ), 'YYYY-MM') AS "calendar_month"
    FROM
      public.dim_calendar
    where
      date >= '2015-01-01'
      and date <= getdate()+interval '30 day';;
    __sql_trigger_value: SELECT CURRENT_DATE__ ;;
    distribution_style: all
    sortkeys: ["date"]
  }
 

**How is this affecting the client?**

>Our management is very concerned about data reliability in looker.

**Where are we going?**

I'm on leave for the next 10 days or so, but I'm not happy that I've investigated all the possible causes of this issue. I'd like someone to verify what I have found (i.e. nothing!) and see if I missed anything.

**Anything else we should be aware of?**

Because this was reported to Nick, I do have doubts whether there is actually anything going on at all that is out of the ordinary. Dashboard auto-refresh is not turned on, so the dashboard could have been run 20 hours before the user saw it, and they thought everything was out of date. However, Nick says 'clear cache and refresh' didn't update the data, and he could see that the updated data was available via SQL Runner, so....?


**Who did I notify?**

Paola

# Summary so far by: _Noah_
Alright, so this ticket began with you guys (Amina) in Dublin and carried over. A lot of stuff went down with these guys over the course of the day so I'll break it up based on subject. Overall theme here is that these guys don't quite know too much about their own Looker set up because apparently they outsourced their development of SSO Embedding to third party consulting companies or something. The CS team doesn't seem to know what they are doing as well because of them outsourcing all of this work. Nor do they really understand the basic architecture of Looker. So it took a long time to really get to what was wrong (and I still dont _really_ know to be honest.

From Amina's ticket we thought the issue was an API call not finding a schedule. This was resolved in our point of view. The get schedules endpoint returns schedules **owned** by the user calling this endpoint. They were calling a get schedule and getting blank results, because the user didnt own any schedules. This schedule they though they should have been getting doesn't exist, either it was deleted or was never created. i__looker queries in this chat. 

Next stuff comes from this ticket: #192964

They kept mentioning how their schedule wouldn't show up in their third party app, and I was super confused about this. So I asked a couple times if they could send me the api call/sdk or any code that dictated whether we were talking about the API or embedding, because I was hoping I'd see either an iframe or some SDK call like sdk.get... Turns out this was SSO Embedding and they're dashboards are not rendering in their other website. This is the example URL they gave me to check out:

```
convirzadev.looker.com/login/embed/%2Fembed%2Fdashboards%2F258%3Fembed_domain%3Dhttps%3A%2F%2Flocal.convirza.com%26?nonce=%22UFibgsSKJkkLawrj%22&time=1548798352&session_length=86400&external_user_id=2&permissions=%5B%22see_user_dashboards%22%2C%22see_lookml_dashboards%22%2C%22access_data%22%2C%22see_looks%22%2C%22see_drill_overlay%22%2C%22schedule_look_emails%22%2C%22schedule_external_look_emails%22%2C%22download_with_limit%22%2C%22download_without_limit%22%2C%22save_content%22%5D&models=%5B%22cfa_reports_model%22%2C%22convirza_model%22%5D&access_filters=%7B%7D&first_name=%22Bill%22&last_name=%22Joe%22&group_ids=%5B%5D&external_group_id=%22awesome_engineers%22&user_attributes=%7B%22host_name%22%3A%22local.convirza.com%22%2C%22api_url%22%3A%22localhost%22%2C%22ct_user_id%22%3A2%2C%22access_token%22%3A%22%20a690fe64-7060-444a-ad8b-990a822969d9%22%2C%22role_id%22%3A1%7D&force_logout_login=true&user_timezone=%22America%2FDenver%22&signature=hxUuaVtyhDmFf5Ajz1pKKYdTydg%3D 
```

So checking out this dashboard 258 in the **dev** instance and all the schedules built off of it is the next step in the epic journey. Be very careful when chatting with them, I think they were opening chats in one instance and asking questions about stuff in the other instance, which is why it took so long to realize stuff. So very clearly ask about dev vs prod instance for everything. They're colleagues Rahul and Ajay _should_ know more about their third party app thats embedding stuff. Its pretty difficult to get answers out of Sanket though.

**What's been covered so far?**

> I downloaded the logs for today & ran timings on them. I've attached both of those files. There doesn't seem to be anything that stands out though other than what was already mentioned, they had about 10 users run the same dashboard at once and CPU went up. Their CPU over the past few days seems extremely low/healthy so I'm not convinced that they need to upsize their instance. Instead, we should recommend that they try using the same underlying queries for some of the tiles on their dashboards. For example, the YTD tiles on the dashboard: https://4finance.eu.looker.com/x/4ry7f5s12xfMnQViB42O27 and https://4finance.eu.looker.com/x/sIrtjCz3b14A1Qa24NNj6k . **How is this affecting the client?**

looker 2678 111 75.8 14793116 11679352 ? Sl 22:05 6:56 java -Dcom.sun.akuma.Daemon=daemonized -XX:+UseG1GC -XX:MaxGCPauseMillis=2000 -Xms10780663k -Xmx10780663k -verbose:gc -XX:+PrintGCDetails -XX:+PrintGCTimeStamps -Xloggc:/tmp/gc.log -jar looker.jar start --ssl-keystore=/home/looker/looker/.ssl/looker.jks --ssl-keystore-pass-file=/home/looker/looker/.ssl/.keystorepass --staging --scheduler-threads=0
root 3225 0.0 0.0 10460 936 pts/0 S+ 22:12 0:00 grep --color=auto java
# send a request to ops to take a look to this
# solved in 153077

#!/bin/sh

 

cd /opt/looker

# set your java memory- there should be over 1.5G of system memory

# left to run the OS

MEM=`cat /proc/meminfo | grep MemTotal | awk '{print $2}'`

JM=`expr $MEM \* 6 / 10`

JAVAMEM="${JM}k"

 

# Get proxy settings

. /etc/fitbit/include/proxy.sh

unset http_proxy

unset https_proxy

 

# Extra Java startup args and Looker startup args. These can also be set in

# a file named lookerstart.cfg

JMXARGS="-Dcom.sun.akuma.jvmarg.com.sun.management.jmxremote -Dcom.sun.akuma.jvmarg.com.sun.management.jmxremote.port=9910 -Dcom.sun.akuma.jvmarg.com.sun.management.jmxremote.ssl=false -Dcom.sun.akuma.jvmarg.com.sun.management.jmxremote.local.only=false -Dcom.sun.akuma.jvmarg.com.sun.management.jmxremote.authenticate=true -Dcom.sun.akuma.jvmarg.com.sun.management.jmxremote.access.file=${HOME}/.lookerjmx/jmxremote.access -Dcom.sun.akuma.jvmarg.com.sun.management.jmxremote.password.file=${HOME}/.lookerjmx/jmxremote.password"

 

# to set up JMX monitoring, add JMXARGS to JAVAARGS

JAVAARGS="-Dhttp.proxyHost=$PROXY_HTTP_HOST -Dhttp.proxyPort=$PROXY_HTTP_PORT -Dhttp.nonProxyHosts=127.0.0.1|localhost -Dhttps.proxyHost=$PROXY_HTTP_HOST -Dhttps.proxyPort=$PROXY_HTTP_PORT"

LOOKERARGS=""

 

# check for a lookerstart.cfg file to set JAVAARGS and LOOKERARGS

if [ -r ./lookerstart.cfg ]; then

 . ./lookerstart.cfg

fi

 

start() {

 if [ -e .deploying ]; then

 echo "Startup suppressed: ${PWD}/.deploying file exists. Remove .deploying file to allow startup"

 exit 1

 fi

 

 LOCKFILE=.starting

 if [ -e ${LOCKFILE} ] && kill -0 `cat ${LOCKFILE}`; then

 echo "Startup suppressed: ${LOCKFILE} contains running pid, startup script is already running"

 exit 1

 fi

 

 # make sure the lockfile is removed when we exit and then claim it

 trap "rm -f ${LOCKFILE}; exit" INT TERM EXIT

 echo $$ > ${LOCKFILE}

 

 fixcrypt

 java \

 -XX:+CMSClassUnloadingEnabled -XX:+UseConcMarkSweepGC \

 -XX:MaxPermSize=128M -Xms$JAVAMEM \

 -Xmx$JAVAMEM \

 -verbose:gc -XX:+PrintGCDetails -XX:+PrintGCTimeStamps \

 -Xloggc:/tmp/gc.log ${JAVAARGS} \

 -jar looker.jar start ${LOOKERARGS}

 

 if [ -x ./tunnel ]; then

 ./tunnel start

 fi

 

 rm -f ${LOCKFILE}

}

 

stop() {

 pid=`cat .tmp/looker.pid`

 if [ -f .status_server_token ] && [ -x /usr/bin/curl ]; then

 state="running"

 token=`cat .status_server_token`

 request="control/stop?token=${token}"

 timeout 20 curl -m 10 -ks https://127.0.0.1:9999/${request} > /dev/null 2>&1

 ECODE=$?

 [ $ECODE -eq 7 ] && state="stopped"

 if [ $ECODE -gt 7 ] ; then

 kill $pid

 fi

 for i in {1..30}; do

 timeout 20 curl -m 5 -ks https://127.0.0.1:9999/alive > /dev/null 2>&1

 ECODE=$?

 if [ $ECODE -eq 7 ]; then

 state="stopped"

 break

 fi

 if [ $ECODE -gt 7 ] ; then

 kill -9 $pid

 fi

 sleep 1

 done

 if [ "${state}" = "running" ]; then

 echo "Force Stop Looker Web Application"

 kill $pid

 kill -0 $pid && kill -9 $pid

 fi

 else

 timeout 20 java -jar looker.jar stop

 if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then

 kill -9 $pid

 fi

 fi

}

 

fixcrypt() {

 CRYPTEXIST=`/sbin/ldconfig -p | grep -c '\slibcrypt.so\s'`

 

 if [ $CRYPTEXIST -eq 0 ]; then

 if [ ! -d .tmp ]; then

 mkdir .tmp

 fi

 CRYPTLN=`/sbin/ldconfig -p | grep '\slibcrypt\.so\.[[:digit:]]' | awk '{print $(NF)}'`

 ln -s -f $CRYPTLN `pwd`/.tmp/libcrypt.so

 export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=`pwd`/.tmp/:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH

 fi

}

 

case "$1" in

 start)

 start

 ;;

 stop)

 stop

 ;;

 restart)

 echo "Restarting Looker Web Application" "looker"

 stop

 sleep 3

 start

 ;;

 status)

 curl -ks https://127.0.0.1:9999/alive > /dev/null 2>&1

 if [ $? -eq 7 ]; then

 echo "Status:Looker Web Application stopped"

 exit 7

 else

 echo "Status:Looker Web Application running"

 exit 0

 fi

 ;;

 *)

 java -jar looker.jar $*

 ;;

esac

 

exit 0
Zendesk Tickets Summary: Fitbit was having issues with their Looker instance and when we had them try to restart it, they ended up with a corrupted jar file and java version returning Java 7. Once upgrading java and pulling down a jar from s3, all was well. Going to try and get on a post mortem with them and Ryan to get as much info as we can.
Customer updated and broke the world. They were setting their java version to the wrong version in the startup script.

## From email:

Oh no!

Looks like they are [no longer on No Update](https://meta.looker.com/explore/meta/check?qid=VBTf26qB4II0v1Is649pT8&origin_space=103&toggle=pik), but there's no note indicating why that might have happened. Based on [their update dates](https://meta.looker.com/explore/meta/check?qid=VBTf26qB4II0v1Is649pT8&origin_space=103&toggle=pik), it seems possible that it never stuck. I'll see if we can audit what happened in the License server.

Rolling their instance back would require going to a backup on Looker 5.2 or before, so they'd lose all non-LookML work done since 12/13 (users created, Looks, Dashboards, etc.). 

I'll move this information to the ticket so whomever grabs it can see it.

-- Carter

On Mon, Jan 22, 2018 at 10:56 AM, Ashley Berry <ashley.berry@looker.com> wrote:
Hi Carter, Hilary, 

Hope you both had a nice weekend! 

NexRep submitted a ticket this morning (#120844) because they're experiencing a number of LookML errors. 

We moved them to the 'no update list' in December but it looks like they were upgraded to version 5.4.13.

Is it possible to roll them back to their prior version?

Thank you! 
Ashley

## HST Summary 

- Business Impact: Update to 5.14.6 caused > 1000 LookML errors to be thrown because of improper use of ${} syntax in DTs, despite the fix to replace errors with warnings. All queries were failing to run due to these errors. 

- What have we done: Rolled back 5.12, which has resolved errors. Fix being backported to 5.14. 

- Where are we going: Rollback working well for today, customer will be re-updated to 5.14 during next maintenance hours. 

- Best bet ETA: Solved

Angaza Engineering, Apr 10, 22:42 EAT

Hi Clarice,

Thanks for bringing this to our attention. After investigating this issue, we discovered that the database that we use to perform our exports to your Redshift cluster fell out of sync for approximately 20 minutes on Mar 12 from 1820h until 1840h, which also corresponded with our export to GLP Uganda's payments table.

There were 85 total payments that were not reflecting in GLP's Uganda Redshift payments table. I've attached a list of the payment's Angaza IDs, but let me know if you'd like additional data on the payments.

I've manually exported these payments, so they are now present in your Redshift cluster.

As part of this investigation, we'll put steps in place to detect future synchronization problems to ensure this problem won't happen again in the future.

Thanks,

Bill | Angaza Engineering
